title: Youngsters 'most likely' to cheat travel insurance
text:
Youngsters 'most likely' to cheat travel insurance 9 July 2015 | By Hannah Wigman Save 
Youngsters are more likely to cheat their travel insurance than any other age group, a new study has found. 
Recent research by gocompare.com has revealed that 18 to 34 year olds to be the most likely age group to commit travel insurance fraud. 
A total of 17% of 18 to 24 year olds and 12% of people aged 25 to 34 admitted to wrongly claiming on their travel insurance, on average trying to get an extra £370 per head from insurers. 
The survey lead to 5% of Brits overall admitting to either exaggerating or making up travel claims of £298 on average. 
It also showed that 2% of people have invented a travel claims before, a further 2% admitted to having added value to a claim, and another 2% added several hundred pounds to a real claim to make it more ‘worthwhile’. 
Travel insurance fraud of this type costs policyholders millions of pounds every year, making it a growing issue. 
False claims are a criminal offence and those who do so and are caught face a number consequences, including more difficulty both getting, and claiming, insurance in the future. 
Gocompare.com Travel Insurance spokesperson Caroline Lloyd said: “The vast majority of travel insurance claims are genuine and insurers will always look to pay-out honest claims. 
“When buying insurance it’s important to read the small print. This will explain what’s covered and what’s not, as well as policy limits, excesses and guidelines for making claims - such as obtaining a written police report if you have been a victim of theft. Our survey found that only a fifth of people do this.”
